componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on the ETP. In particular, just trying to get an understanding for what types of hotels are signed up at this point? It looks like it's around 8% of total properties. What types of hotels and then if you have any target for the timing and sort of how quickly those can be rolled out? And also, just curious if those hotels are especially promoted on the site in some way?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we get about 13,000 hotels signed up so far. About 9,000 of those are hotels that we would classify as chain hotels or strategic accounts, with the remaining being independents. We had a great reception from our chain partners and we're pretty ex
componenttext: Sure. So we get about 13,000 hotels signed up so far. About 9,000 of those are hotels that we would classify as chain hotels or strategic accounts, with the remaining being independents. We had a great reception from our chain partners and we're pretty excited to be working with them on this. In terms of the rollout plan, we've got about 3,000 of those hotels actually live right now. It takes some time to actually get them trained up and converted over to the new platform. And we will plan, by the end of the year, to have significantly more live. We have the functionality essentially rolled out on the majority of Hotels.com websites now, either with 100% of traffic or 50-50 in testing. And I would say the same for Expedia, there a little bit behind in rolling it out just because of the technology. And by the end of the year, we expect to have the functionality live on both brand Expedia and Hotels.com globally. In terms of Brand Expedia the how fast will roll out new properties, again, we kind of get the flexibility here to see some of the trends that we see and accelerate or decelerate. But so far, we like what we see and we're going to continue to rollout according to our plan. We have not done any special promotion of participating hotels. But we have seen that hotels that are participating are generally getting significantly more volume than those that don't. And really, that's driven by the fact that consumers really like this product. And so they're just more likely to book with those hotels if they've got the choice versus those they don't. And the other thing we're seeing is that hotels the participate are generally get bookings on average of longer lengths of stay, which is a great results for our hotel partners. More volume, bookings with longer length of stay is a good thing. And then the last thing I would note is that again, it's early, but so far, we're seeing this model be significantly more attractive to consumers outside of the U.S. than it is in the U.S. European consumers really like that and we that'll be a great thing for our hotel partners driving more International business into the U.S. hotels. And I think it'll be a great thing for our business in terms of giving us more opportunity to expand internationally. But again, it's very early to tell. We're excited with what we see. We'll update you when we know more.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I'd just add that at this point, ETP's not an important factor in our results one-way or the other. And as it roles, we'll tell you more about it. But this quarter really wasn't about ETP. The next couple of quarters hopefully will be.
componenttext: And I'd just add that at this point, ETP's not an important factor in our results one-way or the other. And as it roles, we'll tell you more about it. But this quarter really wasn't about ETP. The next couple of quarters hopefully will be.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Naved Khan with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Naved Khan with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Based on the conversion rate improvement, I was wondering if I could get a sense of where you are in the improvement cycle and are you continuing to see more gains on the Hotels.com brand that's one of the brands where obviously, you started sort of to ro
componenttext: Based on the conversion rate improvement, I was wondering if I could get a sense of where you are in the improvement cycle and are you continuing to see more gains on the Hotels.com brand that's one of the brands where obviously, you started sort of to rollout earlier. Can you give us a sense on that one?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Naved, the gains continue both on Hotels.com and on Expedia. This is a -- it's not a one-year thing. It's setting up long-term processes where you can optimize your site where you can experiment at very fast rates and we have not seen the conversion
componenttext: Yes, Naved, the gains continue both on Hotels.com and on Expedia. This is a -- it's not a one-year thing. It's setting up long-term processes where you can optimize your site where you can experiment at very fast rates and we have not seen the conversion gains at Hotels.com stop. And having the 2 teams, having Hotels.com and Expedia, the Hotwire teams, even the Egencia teams, all experimenting faster based on agile technology, allows the different teams to compare notes. We're comparing notes with our great friends in eLong as well. And we think it kind of creates a pretty interesting environment as far as getting better and better selling hotels on a global basis as a family of brands.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you talk about China and basically, comment on what kind of trends you're seeing there in terms of the level of promotion activity and the level of discounting that might be going on there?
componenttext: Okay. And then can you talk about China and basically, comment on what kind of trends you're seeing there in terms of the level of promotion activity and the level of discounting that might be going on there?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll leave eLong to get into more commentary as far as China goes. They'll dedicate a whole call to it. But we've been very, very pleased with our progress in China. eLong has been gaining share in that marketplace against the top %layer for some per
componenttext: Yes, I'll leave eLong to get into more commentary as far as China goes. They'll dedicate a whole call to it. But we've been very, very pleased with our progress in China. eLong has been gaining share in that marketplace against the top %layer for some period of time. We don't believe that those trends are going to stop anytime soon. And there has been very aggressive discounting in that marketplace, which while difficult for short term profits, we think is driving a lot of consumers to book online than we think over the long term, in addition to the share gains, we think that's just the benefit. The more people come online, the faster in a market like China, look better for ourselves and even our competitors in the Chinese market. So we're pretty pleased with where we are there and we expect the eLong team to keep competing, keep executing effectively.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my last question, was there any impact from the Olympics, positive or negative?
componenttext: Okay. And then my last question, was there any impact from the Olympics, positive or negative?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: There was a slight impact but, I think that the Olympic impact in general is not one that's large enough to -- that wasn't large enough to really affect our numbers. We did observe a healthy U.K. market post-Olympics. So the U.K. really picked up and that
componenttext: There was a slight impact but, I think that the Olympic impact in general is not one that's large enough to -- that wasn't large enough to really affect our numbers. We did observe a healthy U.K. market post-Olympics. So the U.K. really picked up and that's certainly a good thing.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Herman Leung with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Herman Leung with Susquehanna.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great quarter, guys. Two quick questions for you. I guess on the take rates when you think about the agency side, I was just wondering whether you can talk about the difference between the agency take rates in the U.S. versus agency take rates you might b
componenttext: Great quarter, guys. Two quick questions for you. I guess on the take rates when you think about the agency side, I was just wondering whether you can talk about the difference between the agency take rates in the U.S. versus agency take rates you might be seeing in the different regions that you're seeing out there. And then the second question is there's obviously, been a lot of chatter about a potential 3 55 exchange with Liberty. Wondering if that is something that is -- something that you guys are thinking about with CruiseShipCenters and/or maybe another property, combined with cash. And I have a very quick follow-up.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with respect to take rates, we're not getting into the specific details. I would just point you generally to some of the pressures that you've seen on our revenue per room night over the course of the last few quarters.We've called out mix into
componenttext:
Sure. So with respect to take rates, we're not getting into the specific details. I would just point you generally to some of the pressures that you've seen on our revenue per room night over the course of the last few quarters.
We've called out mix into non-U.S. regions and mix into chain hotels. So to the extent that ETP as a product drives greater mix into chain hotels or greater mix outside of the U.S., you could expect that to put revenue per room night pressure on the business. But again, that's pressure that we like, that's pressure that is driven by volume related mix shift. So it's an investment that we are very happy to make.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And as far as Liberty goes, we've read some of the liberties comments publicly. They've been a great partner for us. They've been terrific board members, very, very constructive. And we're quite happy to have them as investors. Liberty is obviously, very
componenttext: And as far as Liberty goes, we've read some of the liberties comments publicly. They've been a great partner for us. They've been terrific board members, very, very constructive. And we're quite happy to have them as investors. Liberty is obviously, very active on the transactional front. But at this point, I think there's nothing really to say. Our philosophy on our own balance sheet is that we want to put our considerable cash flows to good use. And over the long term, we've been shrinking our capital base for some period of time, and that's not going to change one-way or the other. But to the extent that Liberyt is interested in different structures, we'll talk to them. But at this point, it's nothing more than the comments that we've heard.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And you also talked about the -- earlier in your comments, you talked about the international POS systems up about 50% or 50% of your total transactions. Is there a way you can give us a breakdown between the drivers of that between affiliate and Expedia
componenttext: And you also talked about the -- earlier in your comments, you talked about the international POS systems up about 50% or 50% of your total transactions. Is there a way you can give us a breakdown between the drivers of that between affiliate and Expedia brands?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Pretty strong across the board. The Brand Expedia has been getting stronger in general, Hotels.com has been doing incredibly well internationally. The -- business has been doing internationally as well. So it's been pretty broad strength across our variou
componenttext: Pretty strong across the board. The Brand Expedia has been getting stronger in general, Hotels.com has been doing incredibly well internationally. The -- business has been doing internationally as well. So it's been pretty broad strength across our various brands and businesses.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Olsen of Piper Jaffray Piper.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Olsen of Piper Jaffray Piper.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Andrew Connor in for Mike.Just the risk of beating a dead horse, wanted to really understand the performance specifically in Europe. I'm just wondering if really, Europe is a situation in which Expedia's out executing it's peers in an otherwise
componenttext:
This is Andrew Connor in for Mike.
Just the risk of beating a dead horse, wanted to really understand the performance specifically in Europe. I'm just wondering if really, Europe is a situation in which Expedia's out executing it's peers in an otherwise deteriorating macro, or if the Europe macro is maybe a bit more resilient than you had thought and adding a modest tailwind to your business?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's really hard again for us to comment on the overall impact of macro on the market. And the reason is, is that we are still fairly small in Europe. And Europe is a very attractive market and one where we have had for some time, I would say l
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's really hard again for us to comment on the overall impact of macro on the market. And the reason is, is that we are still fairly small in Europe. And Europe is a very attractive market and one where we have had for some time, I would say less than best-in-class execution. So as we rolled out the new platforms and been executing on our PlayBooks, we have considerable headroom to grow in Europe. And so to some extent, we end up being less hit by macro conditions. At least less hit than we can see because we are in a share gain mode. Now if the economy there was really booming, perhaps it would be higher. But again, that's very difficult for us to tell.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tracy Young with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tracy Young with Evercore.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a question on VIA Travel since you already touched upon the overall travel. If you could talk about any impact that you can see on corporate travel in Europe, and if maybe that could've been a bigger contributor to your bottom line, top line and bott
componenttext: Just a question on VIA Travel since you already touched upon the overall travel. If you could talk about any impact that you can see on corporate travel in Europe, and if maybe that could've been a bigger contributor to your bottom line, top line and bottom line.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: VIA Travel is actually -- it's getting really well. We're getting to know the 2 team. I'm really impressed with the talent of the team there. The -- it's growth and northern Europe in general, if you look at Europe, northern Europe where quite a bit of VI
componenttext: VIA Travel is actually -- it's getting really well. We're getting to know the 2 team. I'm really impressed with the talent of the team there. The -- it's growth and northern Europe in general, if you look at Europe, northern Europe where quite a bit of VIA Travel's business is concentrated in seems to be outperforming the rest of the continent so to speak. And as a result of via is overperforming versus at least the deal case that we had out there, and we're quite positive on the business and we're quite positive on that theme.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Janice Simson from credit cease.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Janice Simson from credit cease.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm on for Stephen Ju. Can you share anything with us in terms of the cadence of the quarter, whether it's deteriorated or improved as the quarter went on for the various regions? And two, just to turn to air ticket growth, accelerated significantly from
componenttext: I'm on for Stephen Ju. Can you share anything with us in terms of the cadence of the quarter, whether it's deteriorated or improved as the quarter went on for the various regions? And two, just to turn to air ticket growth, accelerated significantly from the previous quarter. I was hoping you could provide some color on the drivers of that.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I would say the quarter was fairly consistent. We did see -- I would say strength build a little bit as the quarter progressed. So that was a good sign. But nothing super significant that was pretty steady improvement as it unfolded. With respect
componenttext: Sure. So I would say the quarter was fairly consistent. We did see -- I would say strength build a little bit as the quarter progressed. So that was a good sign. But nothing super significant that was pretty steady improvement as it unfolded. With respect to the air ticket growth, the real driver there was VIA Travel with respect to it's a big corporate travel business, which is pretty air heavy and so that drives really the bulk of that growth. And without VIA Travel, the growth would've been closer to the lower single-digit range.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And for the cadence of the quarter, it was pretty consistent across all geographies.
componenttext: And for the cadence of the quarter, it was pretty consistent across all geographies.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say the impact was pretty consistent across all geographies, slight acceleration as we move through the quarter.
componenttext: Yes, I would say the impact was pretty consistent across all geographies, slight acceleration as we move through the quarter.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Millman with Millman research Associates.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Millman with Millman research Associates.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, I'm wondering, considering the quick impact, relative quick impact of mobile's and the innovation taking place, does this give you some pause regarding longevity of your platforms and technology spend? Also, just a housekeeping -- you seem not to h
componenttext: First, I'm wondering, considering the quick impact, relative quick impact of mobile's and the innovation taking place, does this give you some pause regarding longevity of your platforms and technology spend? Also, just a housekeeping -- you seem not to have the transaction numbers maybe if you can give it to us and hopefully, it'll be back in the future. And then the usual U.S. car rental update as to third and fourth quarter outlook on fleet price opaque availability and maybe what's creating the pricing disruption?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, I'll call without you asking about cars would not be an Expedia call. So we're happy to tell you all about that. Mark is going to answer cars. But as far as platforms go, listen, I think it's a great question. The -- what the challenge for us now
componenttext: Michael, I'll call without you asking about cars would not be an Expedia call. So we're happy to tell you all about that. Mark is going to answer cars. But as far as platforms go, listen, I think it's a great question. The -- what the challenge for us now as we build out technology and as we build out designs for our various sites, is to build those designs in an adaptive way. That means that they can adapt to the form factor that the user chooses. So the user is on a PC, the site adapts to the size of that PC. If they are on iPad mini, the site also adapts to that iPad mini. It creates more upfront work as far as the kind of design that you do, decisions on what's really important present on a page versus what's not important to present on the page. In general, our sites are not adaptive at this point, in general. And as we're building out new feature sets, as we're redesigning pages, we'll look to design them in an adaptive way, so that they can adapt freely to the various devices that you -- that the user wants to use. And listen, we think this is a -- this is an opportunity for technology companies out there, for technology leaders out there. This is -- it's going to be a challenge to build out adaptive designs in general. It's something that we think can differentiate us, but it is an upfront cost. It's just the fragmentation of the devices on a worldwide basis is going to make our jobs more complex but I think that, that allows us to differentiate ourselves and to add value in the general travel value chain. Mark is going to take on the other questions.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So transaction, that's a metric that we just actually just don't look at internally anymore. There's so much in our business that's driven by product mix shift. That metric itself has become much less meaningful than room nights and air ticket and c
componenttext: Sure. So transaction, that's a metric that we just actually just don't look at internally anymore. There's so much in our business that's driven by product mix shift. That metric itself has become much less meaningful than room nights and air ticket and car days, which we look at internally. So we're striving to basically give you guys metrics that we use to understand the business and help you understand the business and transactions was increasingly becoming less so that type of number. With respect to what we're seeing in car, we did see some compression in the summer. And that, of course, made opaque inventory a little bit more scarce. We are not expecting a meaningful change in that situation as we move into Q4. We are expecting still some compression. And for our business, there wasn't anything materially that changed in the quarter. Again, we did have some weakness in our opaque inventory. But that ultimately got offset for us anyways in terms of some uplift that we saw from some Brand Expedia improvement in the car product.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Post with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Post with Bank of America.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan calling in for Justin. I guess first, given what you guys talked about regarding the timing of the marketing spend versus when you booked, how do you think that we should begin to measure really the marketing efficiency for you guys? Is it be
componenttext: This is Ryan calling in for Justin. I guess first, given what you guys talked about regarding the timing of the marketing spend versus when you booked, how do you think that we should begin to measure really the marketing efficiency for you guys? Is it better to look at it on a percentage of bookings or revenue? Just kind of want to get your thoughts around that. And then secondly, you talked about the transfer of the Expedia room nights. I was just wondering if you're also willing to break out that for Hotels.com.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So listen, given the best way to model marketing efficiencies is by brand, by geography. But of course, you don't have that. So the next closest thing you probably got in quarter is specifically merchant gross bookings and our hotel spend. Of course
componenttext: Sure. So listen, given the best way to model marketing efficiencies is by brand, by geography. But of course, you don't have that. So the next closest thing you probably got in quarter is specifically merchant gross bookings and our hotel spend. Of course, Expedia Traveler Preference could make that a little bit more difficult to track over time, so it may be a temporary fix. But that's probably the closest. It is not perfect though, of course. We've got multiple products that are in merchant and multiple things that we spend our marketing money on, including brand marketing, which can generally move the numbers because its less tied to specifically in-quarter activity. But hopefully, that gives you a little bit of guidance. In terms of trends for room nights for Hotels.com, I would say that the Hotels.com and the rest of the brand, the trend has been pretty consistent. They continue to perform at a healthy level, healthy growth rates. We haven't seen anything materially change in that. And as Dara said, a lot of the changes that we've made in the hotel platform and really the way that we're executing on the business playbook should be things that we believe give continued growth in that business. And that's -- in all of those businesses, and that's certainly what we are seeing.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And Ryan, the only thing I'd add on the relationship of marketing to our other metrics is, don't judge us by our marketing spend versus revenue or bookings on a quarterly basis. We don't run the basis -- run the business on a quarterly basis. We obviously
componenttext: And Ryan, the only thing I'd add on the relationship of marketing to our other metrics is, don't judge us by our marketing spend versus revenue or bookings on a quarterly basis. We don't run the basis -- run the business on a quarterly basis. We obviously -- it's really important to keep track of your trends and make sure that you're keeping operational execution discipline. But we are building this business for the long term. And sometimes, if we invest in one quarter, it may not pay off until a few quarters down the road or a few years. And that's not going to stop us from making that investment.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Kopelman with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Kopelman with Cowen & Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you give us more color on how customers are engaging through smartphones and tablets? You disclosed the 20% of Hotwire transactions, are mobile devices also a meaningful driver for Expedia as a whole?
componenttext: Can you give us more color on how customers are engaging through smartphones and tablets? You disclosed the 20% of Hotwire transactions, are mobile devices also a meaningful driver for Expedia as a whole?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, they are. Their meaningful Expedia is over 10%. Right now, mobile, if you look at Expedia and its product, right now, Expedia really has a hotel product available on its iPad app. We're coming up with pretty soon with a -- with air experience on our
componenttext: Yes, they are. Their meaningful Expedia is over 10%. Right now, mobile, if you look at Expedia and its product, right now, Expedia really has a hotel product available on its iPad app. We're coming up with pretty soon with a -- with air experience on our iOS app, which really, really looks beautiful. But in general, when you look at hotels or Hotwire, they are ahead with Expedia as we add on more products because Expedia is a multiproduct business, we expect our mobile transaction penetration to increase. The hotel experiences' great. But we think the air experience is going to be very, very good.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: And is that still primarily last-minute or are you still seeing users branch out?

componenttext: On tablets, it looks very much like on PCs. On the phone, it tends to be more last-minute activity.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Nishant for Scott. Just wanted an update on the impact of I guess, Google's initiative in travel, how you see that Expedia in terms of both Hotel Finder and then the other products that they have?
componenttext: This is Nishant for Scott. Just wanted an update on the impact of I guess, Google's initiative in travel, how you see that Expedia in terms of both Hotel Finder and then the other products that they have?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: The quick update is that we're not seeing an effect on our overall business. We obviously, Google is a valuable partner of ours. They're a long-term partner, and we do a lot of business with Google on that business in general is increasing. The Hotel Find
componenttext: The quick update is that we're not seeing an effect on our overall business. We obviously, Google is a valuable partner of ours. They're a long-term partner, and we do a lot of business with Google on that business in general is increasing. The Hotel Finder product hasn't been a significant producer for us. We participate in Hotel Finder but I think at this point, Google is doing lots of experimentation. On the air side, initially, when they launched the Air product, it hurts our free traffic to our sites. And Google obviously, has a huge market power and to the extent that they're sending traffic to their own sites, that really hurts any third parties and it hurts kind of the general environment. But over the last quarter, I think that trend haven't changed significantly one-way or the other.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: Thanks. Could you also -- just one more thing, could you talk about maybe the marketing spend ROI on Google versus maybe TripAdvisor and Kayak, just to give us an understanding of the differences between the channels for Expedia?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We consider that pretty competitive data, so that's not data that we're going to want share.
componenttext: We consider that pretty competitive data, so that's not data that we're going to want share.
